#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Protect Acrylic Paint on Wood
#Text=If not applied properly , the paint on wood surfaces can begin to peel and chip over time .
#Text=This is especially true of wood items that see frequent use , are placed in direct sunlight , or were not properly prepared and painted in the first place .
#Text=By preparing your wood properly before you paint and sealing the painted wood afterwards , your painted wood items will maintain their quality for many years to come .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Preparing the Wood before You Paint
#Text=Use a wet cloth to clean the wood .
#Text=Leaving dirt or other particles on the wood can keep it from properly absorbing the paint , primer , and sealant .
#Text=Clean the wood before applying sealant by wiping it down with a damp cloth .
#Text=You can use a tack cloth to pick up any remaining dirt .
#Text=Tack cloths are gauze-like materials treated with a sticky substance and can be purchased at any home improvement store .
#Text=Apply 2 coats of sealant onto the raw wood .
#Text=Brush a thin coat of glossy acrylic medium sealant onto the wood using a dampened sponge or paintbrush .
#Text=Allow the sealant to dry , and then apply another coat to the wood .
#Text=Lightly sand the wood after the second coat of sealant has dried to remove any excess sealant and then wipe it down again with a wet cloth and tack cloth .
#Text=Use a sponge for wood surfaces with grooves and curves and a paintbrush for flat surfaces .
#Text=The sandpaper should be around a 220 grit .
#Text=Apply a coat of primer to help the paint adhere to the wood .
#Text=Using primer provides a surface to which paint can adhere by allowing the wooden surface to regain surface tooth ( ridges and valleys ) .
#Text=An acrylic gesso is probably your best option for using primers .
#Text=You will only need to apply one coat of a high quality primer , lower quality ones might require a second coat .
#Text=Allow the wood to dry and cure .
#Text=In order to maximize paint adhesion , you ’ll need to allow the primer time to dry .
#Text=This could take several hours .
#Text=Once the primer is dry to the touch , you can start applying your paint .
#Text=Protecting the Paint with a Clear Sealant
#Text=Choose a wax-based or polycrylic sealant .
#Text=Wax-based sealants give wooden surfaces more of a flat finish , while polycrylic ones provide a glossier one .
#Text=Water-based polycrylic sealants are the most versatile .
#Text=Before applying your sealant , clean , sand , and wipe down the wood .
#Text=Use a sponge , cloth , or paintbrush to apply the sealant .
#Text=Dip a dampened sponge , cloth , or paintbrush in the sealant , and apply a thin layer of the sealant to the wood .
#Text=Allow the sealant to dry to the touch .
#Text=Cloths are used more for wax-based sealants , sponges for polycrylic sealants applied to surfaces with grooves or curves , and paintbrushes for flat surfaces .
#Text=Apply a second coat of sealant .
#Text=After the first coat of sealant has dried to the touch , repeat the process of applying sealant with a sponge , cloth or paintbrush .
#Text=Doing so will ensure that the painted wood is fully protected .
#Text=Allow the sealant to cure for 2-3 weeks .
#Text=Just because the surface of the wood is dry to the touch does n’t mean that it is fully dry .
#Text=Allow the sealant to dry and cure for 2-3 weeks after application .
#Text=Do not put anything on the surface , because it can cause damage or imperfections .
#Text=In hot or humid weather , sealant can take longer to dry and should be allowed to sit for a longer period of time .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Always apply sealant , paint , and primer by brushing in the direction of the wood grain .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Washcloth
#Text=Tack cloth
#Text=Sandpaper
#Text=Sponge
#Text=Paintbrush
#Text=Sealant
#Text=Primer
#Text=Quick Summary
